In court, Mr. Orren entered a plea of not guilty by reason of mental disease (the “insanity defense”) and underwent a full psychiatric evaluation, including assessment of his sexual history and desires.

As part of his legal case, Mr. Orren underwent a structured sex offender evaluation. He reported that his first sexual contact was at age 12, when his uncle and an 18-year-old male cousin “did things” to him while he was in foster care. They would take him to McDonald’s afterward, “so it was fine.” By the time he was 14 or 15, he was regularly having sex with males and females who ranged in age “from about ten to in their thirties.”

He was unable to answer whether the sexual contact was always consensual, saying, “No one ever called the cops.” As an adult, he said that he preferred having sex with “young girls, because they don’t fight much.” He said that he usually only had sex with adults when he hired prostitutes or prostituted himself in exchange for money or drugs, although he said that sometimes when high, he “might have done stuff that I don’t really remember.”

The structured sex offender evaluation included penile plethysmography, assessment of visual reaction time using Viewing Time (a measure of the amount of time a person looks at a particular photo or other visual representation of a sexually stimulating situation), and a detailed interview about his sexual practices. This evaluation concluded that his main sexual attraction was to girls between the ages of 8 and 13 years.

Mr. Orren’s personal history was significant for multiple childhood disruptions that led to his moving into the foster care system at age 7. At age 9, his first foster mother caught him repeatedly stealing toys and bullying other children. When she reprimanded him, he hit her with a brick, knocking her unconscious. That led to placement in a second foster home. He began using drugs and alcohol at age 11. He was first incarcerated at 13, for shoplifting from an electronics store in order to obtain money for marijuana. At that point, he went back to live with his maternal grandmother, who has episodically provided him a home since then. During those 15 years, he has been arrested at least a dozen times, mostly for drug possession.

Mr. Orren stopped attending school in eighth grade, at about the same time that he was admitted to his first psychiatric inpatient unit. That admission was triggered by his beating his head against a wall “to stop the voices.” He was given a DSM-IV diagnosis of psychosis not otherwise specified, treated with risperidone, and discharged after 1 week. Soon after discharge, he discontinued the antipsychotic medication.

Between the ages of 15 and 28, Mr. Orren regularly abused cocaine and alcohol and often used other substances when they were available. By the time of his arrest, he had had at least seven psychiatric admissions, always for auditory hallucinations and persecutory delusions (usually of a sexual nature). It was not clear which substances he was using prior to and during these episodes of psychosis or whether they were implicated in the development of his psychiatric symptoms. He had also been admitted twice for alcohol detoxification after he went into withdrawal while unable to acquire alcohol. He was consistently nonadherent to any type of outpatient treatment. He maintained sobriety only while in hospitals or jails. When contacted by the consulting psychiatrist, his grandmother pointed out that Mr. Orren had always been “reckless, dishonest, and angry. I don’t think I’ve ever heard him apologize. I love him, but he probably belongs in jail for lots of reasons.”
diagnosis:
1. Unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder
2. Cocaine use disorder
3. Alcohol use disorder
4. Antisocial personality disorder
5. Pedophilic disorder, nonexclusive type, sexually attracted to both
Obsessive compulsive disorder (F42.8)
case: Leroy is a 34 year old male, whose chief complaint is, “I am having intrusive thoughts.” Leroy reports that “since childhood, I have been experiencing intrusive thoughts.” He reports he has met with a number of psychiatrists in the past, and has tried a range of different psychiatric medications. Leroy reports he was recently recommended by his present physician to see a psychiatrist again, given how distressing his intrusive thoughts have become. His previous psychiatrist started him on Zoloft, and gave him recommendation for community based mental health psychotherapist.  Leroy has been taking the Zoloft (200 mg daily) for about 5 years, for what he states his provider thought was “anxiety or depression.” Leroy acknowledges history of periods of “sadness”, stating “yeah sad, sometimes, but not depressed; when things get out of control; its been a while though; when something feels out of reach.” Denied present or past suicidal ideation, and denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. Leroy insists no problems with perceptual distortion or paranoia, and denied thought insertion or thought broadcasting.  Leroy stated that the intrusive thoughts, “first started happening when I was a kid, I was able to cope with them; getting better understanding what they were; ways to get them to go away; calm myself down and regain control and go on with my life; now that is not working.” Leroy states the most recent intrusive thought has been a fear that the chart bus he drives from his local airport to downtown stop will “slide off the road because of ice or snow.” He thinks about this, on average, about 30 to 45 minutes a day.  Leroy endorsed episodes of “panic” and “my body almost feels like its paralyzed; I experience pain from my spine up”, which lasts for a couple of days at a time. With regards to “generalized anxiety”, patient reports “I would have these thoughts about my ailing mother; she has schizophrenia; my body would react to whatever I was thinking about her; my body tenses up when that happens.” Leroy denied any preoccupations about his physical health, nor inability to leave the home because of anxiety. He reports to work regularly, and rarely misses any work unless he is very sick. He says he is never late to work or planned appointments. Leroy has a girlfriend, and says that relationship is going “great.” In his spare time, he continues to join his friends for basketball pickup games and video game nights, which he still enjoys. Leroy does remember a feeling of having to tap the door handle a few times before he opens it, but said this never lasted more than a few second and was not associated with any fear of catastrophic consequences if he did not complete the task.  Leroy acknowledges observed violence/abuse of his parents when growing up, and with harsh parenting to his 3 siblings, patient denied problems with flashbacks, nightmares or hypervigilance associated with the trauma. Patient works second shift, gets home around 1:30 a.m., reports falling asleep at 2:30 a.m. and wakes up at 10/11 a.m., and can typically sleep through the night without interruption. He reports his energy level is “normal through the week.” Denied recent or past mania. Reports contributing stressors are “work --- not the most peaceful environment.” Also reports mother suffers from “type of schizophrenia and for a while she was taking medication and just recently now decided to stop; that’s been going on for quite some time.” Leroy’s urine toxicology returned with marijuana, and TSH level was within normal limits.

diagnosis: Bipolar disorder, most recent episode manic, in remission (F31.74), Alcohol use disorder, initial remission (F10.21), Mood disorder due to a known physiologic condition with manic features (F06.33)
case: Emil is a 22 year old male that reports “my mom wanted us to meet because she spent her whole first therapy session talking to another therapist at her new program about how she feels I need help; I suspect it has to do with my multiple sclerosis (MS), recently losing my fiancé (Lizzy), and after loosing my dog that came with my fiancé. I also lost my career as a farmer.” The patient reports “My girlfriend and I had a good relationship when I used to be able to fish with her; she was a blue blood from the Cape.” Patient reports that he survived being “attacked when I was at a local bar about 4 years ago; the guy smashed a few beer bottles on my head; I had to go to the hospital and they did brain scans; I don’t remember what they said they found.” Patient reports that after that attack, he stopped fishing and started drinking alcohol heavily, at least 8 standard drinks per day, resulting in him missing work, the end of his relationship with his girlfriend, and resulted in getting two DUIs. Patient remembers, “I tried cutting down, but I was never able to do it.” The patient has been sober from alcohol for 76 days now. He denied any other drug use. Patient reports that around two years ago, “I was starting having another MS flare, I stopped being able to sleep for about two weeks and felt angry all the time.” Patient reports during that time he took several last minute trips to Baltimore by train, trying to start a new business and during that time had many sexual indiscretions. He states “people said I was acting strange and that I claimed I was a celebrity that was going to find a cure for autism.” Emil states “I felt like I had endless energy and could take on the world.” The patient reports no similar episodes like that since then, and denied any major mood symptoms since that time. Emil denied recent or past hallucinations, paranoia or thought insertion. Emil reports he never experienced trauma, with the exception of losing his girlfriend and dog. The patient denied any recent problems with depressed, sad, or hopeless mood, and denied problems recent problems with decreased need for sleep and associated elevated energy, racing thoughts, pressured speech or feelings of euphoria. He denied recent or past anxiety or panic, nor OCD.

diagnosis: Bipolar disorder, current episode manic (F31.2)
case: Neveah is a 14 year old girl that comes to her pediatrician with her mother (presently 4 months pregnant) due to “out of control behaviors at home.” The patient appears restless in the exam room and requiring redirection from her mother throughout the visit. The patient frequently punches her mother in the legs, and in the stomach, and the patient even threw her ipad at the pediatrician when she asked the patient what was upsetting her. Most of the patients psychiatric history is gathered from her mother, given how irritable the patient is during the exam. The mother reports Neveah was born 8 weeks pre-mature, spent about 1 month in the neonatal intensive care unit due to problems with breathing, and ultimately discharged home to her care at one month of age. The patient met developmental milestones on or near expected time, and was “clingy” when she was a toddler, but had no problems making friends in daycare and grade school. When patient was about 11 years of age, her biological father left the home to join the military, and has deployed ever since. Around 12 years of age, around summertime, the patient appeared much more talkative, energetic, and would go several days only needing about 3 hours of sleep at night. She was more impulsive during these times, and believed she had super powers to “make her friends get in trouble at school”, even when she was not at school herself. She was never tired the following day. During that same period, she had many temper tantrums throughout the day, almost every day of the week, that seemed disproportionate to circumstances, like having to have a peanut butter and jelly sandwich instead of a peanut butter and fluff sandwich. The tantrums would last several hours in a day. This pattern of behavior would last for several weeks at a time, with periods of months returning to normal mood and behavior. The patient never appeared to be hallucination or responding to internal stimuli, and never appeared sad or depressed. Neveah had to be hospitalized during an episode like this when she was 13 years old. Neveah refuses to take medications for her symptoms. The start of this year academic year, that patient appeared more calm and in good behavioral control, but began to have similar symptoms of irritability, violence at home, not needing to sleep, talking fast, and property destruction at home.

diagnosis: Acute stress disorder (F43.0)
case: Elain is a 63 year old mother of 5 children and 12 grandchildren, that presents to urgent care with a chief complaint of “I’m hallucinating.” Elain reports no history of depression or manic, and was in her usual state of health until 27 days ago when she witnessed a pedestrian be struck by a moving vehicle in her neighborhood. Elain tried to rescue the pedestrian, and even helped paramedics the responded to the scene provide chest compressions to the pedestrian. Unfortunately the pedestrian was pronounced dead on the scene. Since then, Elain has felt a sense of “dread” and “anxiety” everyday, and feels like every time she hears a cars wheels skid in the street, “I jump out of my skin.” The patient also reports that, when at work, she will have these persistent images of the pedestrian laying in the street, and “I just can’t get the images out of my head.” Elain reports that wakes two or three times a night with nightmares related to the event. Additionally, Elain herself has avoided drying, for fear she will be involved in a car accident herself. She was at work today and decided to come to urgent care because “I was hallucinating” and “I was at my desk and suddenly felt like my body separated from my mind, and I could see myself sitting at my desks, as if I was hovering from above.” Patient denied disorganized speech, thought insertion or thought broadcasting. She denied visual or auditory hallucinations.

diagnosis: Schizophreniform Disorder (F20.81) or F33.3 (Depression with psychotic features)
case: A 19 year old male comes to his primary care off reporting “I think someone has poisoned me at home.” The patient reports that about two and a half months ago, after he lost his job at a local arcade, he started noticing that he was feeling more sleepy at home. He states “I would go to bed around 7 p.m., right after dinner, and not wake up until about 12 p.m. the next day.” He reports before that time, he would go to bed around 10:30 p.m. and wake for work around 6 a.m. He states, “I started to notice that my mom would take longer preparing my plate of food for dinner, and I felt sleepy right after.” He endorsed associated low energy, low motivation and problems with concentration starting around that time. Patient goes on to say “over the past two months, every afternoon when I wake up, I can hear my parents whispering through the vents of the house, planning on killing me and replacing me with a different person.” Patient states he will sometimes also “hear them whispering when I’m at the store getting food and stuff, even though they are all the way back at home.” The patient reports that when he logs onto his ipad to play video games, “I can tell that some of the other characters of the game are my parents pretending to be other people. They are trying to get into my head.” The patient reports over the past 3 weeks he has stopped eating dinner, remains withdrawn to his room, and keeps the shades drawn “because I don’t want them looking into my windows.” The patient denied any other similar periods of symptoms like this in the past, denied illicit substance use (patients urine toxicology returns negative of all substance), and denied recent head injury or seizure. He denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. There are no guns in the home. About halfway through the exam, that patient grabs his jacket and runs out of the doctors office stating “forget it, I can tell you are working with my parents to kill me too.

diagnosis: Polysubstance use disorder, severe (F19.20); Alcohol use, with unspecified alcohol induced disorder (i.e. Beer Pantomania) (F10.99)
case: Stacy is a 54 year old Navy Veteran that comes to the emergency room complaining of “I feel like bugs are crawling all over me.” Patient reports this started about 36 hours ago after returning home from an elective surgical procedure (the patient had a ‘tummy tuck’). Following her surgeons orders, the patient has been on bed rest, abstaining from heavy activity. The patient reports “I also feel incredibly thirsty and I’m shaking like a leaf.” She denied any recent head trauma, and denied history of strokes or seizures. She lives alone in an apartment downtown. She I’ve lost a lot of friends over the years, so I mostly just stay home and delivery food if I’m hungry.” She reports “I have 4 or 5 beers a day”, stating she does not drink more than that “because I’ve been taking Klonopin for about 15 years and those two things do not mix.” The patient does admit, “my PCP stopped prescribing my Klonopin about a year ago, so I buy them from an online dispensary.” She acknowledges sometimes having a beer and Klonopin in the morning, “just to keep the shakes down.” On chart review, you see that the patient has also gone to several local emergency rooms over the past 2 years, with urine toxicology positive for alcohol, benzodiazepines, opiates and amphetamines, although in the controlled substance prescribing database, you see that the patient has never been prescribed opiates or amphetamines. Upon further questioning, that patient does acknowledges she has tried cutting back on alcohol use, since her family and friends has said “it seems like its taking over my life.” Unfortunately, she has not achieved any lengthy sobriety, and has actually found she is drinking more over the past year to achieve a similar effect. Blood labs on this visit indicate severely low sodium and potassium. Patient denied visual hallucinations, auditory hallucinations and denied sad or depressed mood.

diagnosis: Alcohol induced Korsakov’s Syndrome (F10.26); Persistent depressive disorder (F34.1)
case: Collin is a 71 year old man, with remote history of alcohol use disorder, but has been sober for about 6 years. He used alcohol heavily from about 28 years of age to 65 years of age, acknowledging multiple inpatient medical hospitalizations for acute alcohol withdrawal as well as medical complications due to alcohol use, including acute liver failure and subsequent permanent gait abnormalities. He has come to his PCP with his wife reporting, “my family thinks I’m changing.” The wife interrupts the patient and states “you are changing, Collin.” The wife discloses that the patient wandered out of the house into the cold 3 times over the past month, and in the middle of the night. The wife states “I found him outside at about 2 a.m., it was 4 degrees outside and he was in his boxers, just standing there.” The patient himself recalls his wife bringing him inside, but can’t recall going outside. A recent CT scan in the local emergency room indicated no acute abnormalities or indication of stroke. The wife goes on to say, “Collin used to love cooking for the family, but now he can’t find his way around the kitchen”, stating the patient forgets to turn the burners off on the stove and even causes a fire in the kitchen a couple of months ago. The wife reports the family started noticing these changes about 2 years ago. There is no family history of dementia, Parkinson’s or Huntington’s disease. There are no known falls. Collin ultimately discloses “I do feel depressed these days”, reporting a worsening of sad and depressed mood starting about 2 years ago. He endorsed low motivation, anhedonia, and has even had passive suicidal thoughts over the past month. He denied any recent stressors, and denied returning to drinking alcohol or any drug use. Collin’s wife states, “he gets angry of the smallest things.” She goes on to say, “I have to help him get to the bathroom because he is incontinent in the bed very night now”, stating she also has to bath the patient because he can’t find his way around the bathroom. Finally, Collin’s wife states “he goes around making things up when we get around family, sometimes just inventing stuff on the whim, like saying he is making additions to the house or buying a new car, when that is both not true and has nothing to do with the conversation.

diagnosis: Alcohol use disorder, severe (F10.20); Alcohol depended with alcohol-induced psychotic disorder and hallucinations (F10.251); Post traumatic stress disorder (F43.1); Bipolar disorder, most recent episode depressed (F31.30)
case: Patient reports "there was an abrasive attack on my life and I was scared; I went into the emergency room; I let my case manager know I was being harassed by my neighbors; people outside of the community; I tried to let as many people know as possible so I could be safe." Patient reports alcohol use disorder history, associated pancreatitis, with increased drinking recently due to "stress of moving and not being able to be with my dog." Patient reports "I came here to get rest." Reports heavy drinking since 12 years of age, with some sobriety on weekends in early 20's. Reports has recently been drinking 3 of the tall boy beers and "a little brandy." Last drink 5 days ago, but reports has been trying to cut back on drinking over the past 2 weeks. One remote seizure when stopped drinking in the past, but more commonly has shaking and "throwing up non stop." Reports "I hear things; its due to harassment; no one else would know", endorsing some negative commentary auditory hallucinations, which started happening about 2 weeks ago. Denied visual hallucinations, but endorsed thought insertion. Patient reports harassment of "voices of old people that I know from Berlin in High School." Patient acknowledges history of depression, with associated anhedonia, withdrawal, low motivation, decreased appetite and problems with concentration, as well as feelings of isolation, including over the past 3 weeks. Denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. Acknowledges trauma history, not disclosing details, with associated flashbacks, nightmares and hypervigilance, and “I avoid going to bars now.”  Patient acknowledges period about 2 years ago of decreased need for sleep with associated elevated energy, racing thoughts, pressured speech and "I was taking care of my mother going through chemotherapy", which resulted in her being involuntarily hospitalized for about 2 weeks. Patient presently denied other stressors at this time.

diagnosis: Anorexia nervosa, restrictive type (F50.01)
case: Erin is a 16 year old girl that was brought to her pediatric for a routine health exam. Erin is a sophomore at the local high school, plays lacrosse and does ballet at the local arts theatre. Erin reports that she has had no problems with depressed, sad or hopeless mood symptoms, and denied problems with excessive worry or panic. She lives at home with her two mothers, older brother and their dog Fiji. The patient does report that she goes to the gym for about 3 hours each day of the week, during which she does about 2.5 hours of cardiovascular training. She states she skip lunch on most days, has a sliced apple for breakfast, and take her dinner to her bedroom to slowly eat the vegetable portion of dinner (only) over a period of about 3 hours. Menarche was at age 13.5, but she has missed 3 of her last periods. She reports a lot of gastric reflex, and its wakes her up at night time. She also reports “I don’t really have bowel movements anymore, so I take a laxative in the morning and at night time.” She aims to eat less than 1000 calories in a day.

diagnosis: Borderline personality disorder (F60.3); Post traumatic stress disorder (F43.1)
case: Amber is a 37 year old woman, that comes to the emergency room with a chief complaint of “I just want to die.” Amber is well known to this emergency room, sometimes coming to the emergency room with suicidal thinking and plans more than 10 times a week. She has been hospitalized over 40 times in the past 5 years. She has a long history of cutting behaviors, which is currently active, and started around 13 years of age. She reports extensive trauma history, including surviving sexual abuse as a adolescent at home, but then also surviving intimate partner violence in subsequent relationships in her adult hood. She reports “constant” flashbacks, nightmares, and hypervigilance, and now avoids any places where “Im the only woman in the room.” The patient reports her current suicidal thoughts and plan to overdose on all of her medications at home is due to “my girlfriend broke up with me out of the blue; she said I’m too much to handle.” The patient reports present mood of “pissed off”, but denied any recent problems or changes in appetite, energy, motivation or enjoying activities she typically enjoys. Denied recent or past mania or psychosis, and she denied problems with heavy alcohol use or street drug use. She acknowledges that “none of my family talk to me anymore; I only had my girlfriend for support.

diagnosis: Major depressive disorder, moderate, recurrent F33.1; Alcohol use disorder, severe
case: Evan is a 62 year old white man, a Harvard Professor in Economics, with a multi-decade history of heavy alcohol use, but recently sober for approximately 7 months after completing substance rehabilitation in an outpatient settings. Evan presented to the emergency room after taking approximately ten 1 mg Klonopin in one setting, he states was “because I was tired and really wanted to go to sleep.” The patient indicates “I was not trying to kill myself” and “I regret taking that number of tablets at once.” He acknowledges recent discord with his wife, stating “I feel very afraid that she is going to leave me whenever we get into arguments, also indicating that after their most recent argument 2 days prior, he relapsed with alcohol use and drank about 6 standard drinks each of the last 2 days, and was intoxicated at the time of overdose. Patient reports “I used to be so active in teaching at Harvard. Now, I feel like I don’t have purpose”, stating that his department at Harvard has been assigning him less teaching or supervising obligations. The patient denied problems with active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. He denied recent or past symptoms of mania or psychosis. The patient acknowledged recent increased need for sleep, up to 14 hours a day, and still feeling tired when awake. He has had a approximately 10 pound unintentional weight loss over the past month. He acknowledges that there has been a significant increase in difficulty concentrating on texts he used to be able to attend to without issue. He states “sometimes it feels like I’m walking through mud throughout the day”, and “I want to get back to enjoying things in life again.” He acknowledges “sometimes I find myself just crying, but I have no idea why.” He denied feelings of hopelessness or despair. He denied trauma history, nor symptoms of OCD or panic. On arrival to the emergency room, patient acknowledged that he sustained a fall at home, which lead to his coming to the emergency room for evaluation. The patient is noted to have left peri-orbital ecchymosis and small, well-healing abrasions to his forehead. A head CT in the emergency room reveal a 2-3 mm subdural hematoma. The patient denied headache or vision changes in the emergency room. The emergency room clinician completed paperwork for the patient to be admitted on an involuntary basis to inpatient psychiatry. The following day, a repeat head CT revealed the subdural hematoma appeared 5-7 mm in length, yet the patient continued to deny vision changes, headache, confusion or extremity weakness. The patient reports he has been taking Cymbalta for a history of depression for over 5 years, and denied an untoward side effects.
difficulty: Medium given patient minimizing extent of depression and that overdose was suicide attempt, although endorsing neurovegetative, cognitive, motivation, etc symptoms of depression.

diagnosis: Autistic Disorder (F 84.0); Tourette Syndrome (F95.2)
case: Melanie is an 11 year old girl who was brought to urgent care by her mother after being sent home from school for “using racial slurs.” Melanie is the product of a full-term, uncomplicated pregnancy, vaginally delivered with normal APGAR (Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, Respiration) score at birth. Melanie used her first word “Momma” around 48 months of age, and didn’t start noticing other children playing with her until about 6 years old. Even at 6 years old, Melanie would not respond to her name when called, often appearing like she was in a daydream, and would often do a lot of “rocking” or “spinning” when anxious. Melanie’s mother indicates “Melanie is a unique kid. She doesn’t really make good eye contact with me, her father or her friends, and seems to be overly focused on doing puzzles all day. She has a hard time making friends, because all she wants to do is work on puzzles, and does little interactive play with others.” Melanies mother also indicates “if we take her puzzle away from her for dinner, she will have a complete ‘meltdown’ and be inconsolable for a good hour, ultimately leading to us having to give her the puzzle back.” Around 8 years of age, Melanie was found blinking her eyes repeatedly, and would say “I have to do it” whenever family questioned the eye blinking. The eye blinking slowly went away, but seemed to be replace by Melanie contorting her neck repeatedly, and especially when getting ready for school or leaving the house. Now, Melanie slaps herself in the head repeatedly when stressed, to the point that family has to adorn Melanie with soft gloves so she does not cause injury. About 13 months ago, Melanie start screaming out racial slurs when in the grocery store and school, and this would last for about 5 minutes in duration, until she was able to calm down. Otherwise, Melanie denied problems with sad, depressed or hopeless mood, nor problems with auditory or visual hallucinations. Melanies mother denied observations of bizarre rituals such as excessive handwashing, counting or organizing, but does report Melanie has a strong and persistent interest in puzzles. Melanie denied active thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others.
difficulty: Medium given LLM would need to be able to know that Tourette syndrome (vs Tic disorder) can only be diagnosed with both motor AND vocal tics present for at least 12 month duration, which the patient has here.

diagnosis: Cri-du-chat Syndrome (Q93.4) vs Unspecified neurodevelopmental disorder (F89.0)
case: Ben is a 12 month old infant that presented for a well check to their new pediatrician. Ben’s father indicates the Ben has been without any recent infections or sick exposures, and is up-to-date on immunizations. Ben’s father does recount that “Ben looks very different from our other children. His eyes seem to be space father apart, and his ears look much lower than his siblings when they were babies.” Ben’s father also indicates, “we have a hard time leaving him alone for more than 1 minute before he starts crying loudly; his cry sounds very much like a cat.” Ben was born at 4 lbs 5 oz and had to spend about 1 week in the neonatal intensive care unit for what Ben’s dad reports was “something to do with his heart; it was the wrong shape or something.” Ben has had to meet with a pediatric gastroenterologist since birth for problems related to feeding. Ben’s father reports they met with a geneticist about 2 weeks ago, and they are awaiting the results from that testing. On direct exam by pediatrician, the patient is noted to have rather diffuse hypotonia, excessive drooling, a small head and jaw, and a fixed splitting of the second heart sound.
difficulty: Hard. While this diagnosis can be made with the aforementioned clinical signs, confirmation is typically done by genetic testing, which is yet to be determined here.

diagnosis: Hallucinogen persistent perception disorder (F16.983)
case: A 23 year old male presents to urgent care with a chief complaint of “I’m seeing white and black dots everywhere, like a static.” Patient indicates no problems with depressed or sad mood, changes is sleep pattern or duration, nor problems with thoughts, plans or intents of harm to self or others. The patient denied recent or past problems with decreased need for sleep with associated elevated energy, racing thoughts, pressured speech or elevated mood. Denied trauma history nor associated post traumatic stress symptoms. Describes himself as a “typically chill” guy, denying problems with panic, obsessive compulsive disorder symptoms, social anxiety or generalized anxiety. Denied recent or past head trauma or seizures. He denied active use of alcohol, marijuana, PCP or hallucinogens, but does acknowledges having “used a whole bunch of mushrooms at the Burning Man festival when I was 19.” It seems that since his use of mushrooms at this concert, the patient states “I feel like I can see light trails when I’m looking at things and they move.” He also reports seeing “halos” around stationary objects. He denied that the experiences are particularly distressing, and states “I just want to make sure I’m ok.” The patient denied recent or past disorganized speech, disorganized thought process or feelings of paranoia or persecution. The patients complaints were corroborated by his mother who was also in attendance for the appointment.

diagnosis: Adjustment disorder with disturbance in conduct (F43.24) +/- Adjustment disorder with depressed mood (F43.21)
case: Collin is a 13 year old boy that was brought to his pediatrician by his mother for “all he does is talk back and kick me.” Collin appears calm and in good behavioral control in the exam room, but his mother indicates “he was such a good boy until about a week ago when he seemed to be look more sad, not playing his video games like he usually does, and keeping himself in his room.” Collin himself acknowledges “I just have not felt myself; I usually like to go outside and play with friends, but I just don’t feel like I have the energy to do that anymore.” He states his appetite is much less over the past week, but denied any known unintentional weight loss. He acknowledges “I would never kill myself, but I have thought about how the world might be better without me in it.” He denied prior self harm or suicide attempt. Mom reports that about 2 weeks ago the patient’s father lost his job unexpectedly, and the family is now going to have to move to a new state to find new work. The patient reports feeling much more tired during the day now, even after getting about 10 hours of sleep each night. He has had problems concentrating in school, and has failed multiple exams at school over the past week. He denied problems with recent or past mania, psychosis, trauma, substance use or anxiety. Mom states “if he is not sad and crying, he is angry and kicking me”, acknowledging patient has engaged in some light property destruction at home and bullying his younger siblings.
difficulty: Medium. LLM may ‘over diagnosis’ depression instead of adjustment disorder based on duration of symptoms.

diagnosis: Obsessive-compulsive disorder with poor insight (F42.2); hoarding disorder with excessive acquisition (F42.3); major depressive disorder (moderate, recurrent) (F33.1)
case: Patient is a 59-year-old female with an unassessed complex trauma history presenting with not-just-right sensations related to hair and bumps growing on her face that cause substantial distress, despite acknowledging that the hairs and bumps are not always physically present. To manage this distress, she keeps tweezers on her person at all times, checks mirrors every 30 minutes when at home, and avoids staying home for extended periods. She also exhibits contamination concerns manifesting as excessive handwashing (25+ times daily) and using barriers to avoid direct contact with "unclean" surfaces out of fear of contracting an illness. Patient believes that she must act on her physical sensations or contamination-related thoughts most of the time or the distress will persist. Patient also collects items like My Little Ponies and Trolls. She has filled her home, garage, basement, a rented warehouse, and now pays to store items in a neighbor's garage despite saying she has little to no money to pay for these expenses. She expresses strong attachment to these possessions, stating she would "NEVER" sell them, and has a history of repurchasing items she previously attempted to sell. Patient's medical history is significant for AIDS (diagnosed 2003, currently on Odefsey), and past surgical interventions following a car accident. Her psychological history includes previous diagnoses of PTSD and Bipolar Disorder (which she disputes). Current symptoms of a major depressive episode include anhedonia, restlessness, sleep disturbance (averaging 4 hours nightly), feelings of worthlessness, and difficulty concentrating. These episodes emerge roughly every few month. The patient denied symptoms of psychosis as well as symptoms related to higher than usual energy or goal-directed activity at any time in the past. She endorsed suicidal ideation without current plan or intent, rating likelihood of attempt at 1%. Social support is reportedly limited, with the patient living alone with her two dogs, having infrequent contact with her daughter, and minimal social connections beyond casual acquaintances while shopping. She denied distress or functional impairment resulting from any traumatic events.

diagnosis: Obsessive-compulsive disorder, fair insight (F42.2); Recurrent Major Depressive Disorder (mild) (F33.0); antisocial personality disorder (F60.2)
case: The patient is a 25-year-old male who presented with delayed responses and was vaping during intake. He currently works full-time managing his hot tub repair company and lives with his girlfriend. His medical history includes multiple substance addictions, particularly opioids (requiring Suboxone and later Methadone treatment), and previous diagnoses of OCD, ADHD, anxiety disorder, and depressive disorder. He reports a significant history of head trauma (8 concussions), one seizure episode while incarcerated, and multiple incarcerations for offenses including gun possession, burglary, and vehicle theft. His psychiatric medication history includes Adderall, Concerta, Zoloft, an unspecified antidepressant, and Trazodone. The chief complaint involves symptoms that began at approximately age 18 during his first incarceration and have intensified in the past year, coinciding with work stress. Problematic behaviors include arranging items in specific places with extreme rigidity (unable to buy new items that don't have a "place"), performing rituals in sets of three, and a specific handwashing ritual. He experiences intrusive thoughts about harming others (particularly fears of stabbing, shooting, or raping strangers) and engages in compulsive behaviors (brushing his hand from hairline to ear three times) to alleviate associated anxiety. He also reports persistent checking behaviors due to memory doubts, a need for things to feel "just right", and specific ordering rituals. Additionally, he endorses current anhedonia, decreased appetite, fatigue, and concentration difficulties that wax and wane every few months. He shared that these symptoms are distressing, though mildly impairing in his social, work, and leisurely activities. He denies current suicidality, self-harm, or hallucinations/delusions. He reports a childhood history of conduct problems (skipping school, lying, stealing, fighting) and adult behaviors including illegal activities, irresponsibility, deceitfulness (e.g., using fake identifications) and reported guiltlessness after harming others or damaging property. His childhood conduct problems (e.g., fighting) have resulting in the concussions reported in the medical history, and his illegal activities have resulted in two incarcerations. When asked about one such activity (stealing a car), he reported no remorse, instead blaming the victim for calling the police. The assessment revealed that these behaviors have continued for years in multiple settings, though as of late, he reported that he has not engaged in any illegal activities because he does not want to return to jail for a third time.

diagnosis: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder with good insight (F42.2); Gender Dysphoria in Adults, posttransition (F64.0); Major Depressive Disorder, Single Episode, Moderate (F32.1)
case: Patient is a 25-year-old transgender male currently living with parents who are reportedly non-supportive, and he works as a hospital lab technician. He presents with severe symptoms characterized primarily by intrusive thoughts related to morality, contamination, and harm. Unwanted thoughts include fears of transmitting sexual fluids to others (which he believes would make him "a rapist"), concerns about accidentally killing insects, moral distress about consuming animal products, and beliefs that viewing violent media constitutes "condoning" violence. To manage these thoughts, he engages in extensive reassurance seeking, repeatedly checking lab results at work, avoiding video games and television, dietary restrictions, and some handwashing. He reports these symptoms significantly interfere with daily functioning, preventing him from living independently. They cause intense distress that frequently culminates in panic attacks. Patient has a complex history related to his gender identity, reporting he has identified as male throughout his life despite being assigned female at birth. He is currently taking low-dose testosterone but conceals this from his family, who he believes are interfering with his plans for gender-affirming surgeries. He reported childhood "delusions" about being "from a fantasy world and chosen by gods" that resolved by age 18. Patient previously took fluvoxamine for panic symptoms until approximately age 24, reporting significant symptom exacerbation upon discontinuation. He describes himself as introverted with limited social connections, identifying as asexual, though questioning if this might be avoidance related to triggering thoughts. His social anxiety dates back to middle and high school, when he was "pretty much mute" with few friends. Patient describes his mood as "always a little depressed" with recent intensification. He endorses feeling sad, empty, and hopeless most days, anhedonia, sleep disturbances, psychomotor retardation, fatigue, worthlessness, guilt, concentration difficulties, and suicidal ideation. He frequently believes he "needs to be dead" and that suicide would be "the moral thing to do" following morally repugnant intrusive thoughts, though he denies current plan or intent (estimating a 5% chance of suicide within three months). He struggles with activities of daily living without parental support and expresses frustration that his thoughts and behaviors interfere with his gender expression. Despite these significant symptoms, he demonstrates good insight, noting that his thoughts are not consistent with who he is and what he values.

diagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder, recurrent, mild (F33)
case: Patient is a 47-year-old female residing in the Northeastern United States who recently lost her job due to alleged "disorganization", which she contests as the actual reason for termination. Currently unemployed but financially stable for the near term, she is pursuing employment opportunities abroad with plans to relocate to Vietnam in September 2021. The patient lives alone with no local support system and has recently withdrawn from her social connections following concurrent stressors of job loss and the death of her pet cat, expressing irritation with friends' "bad advice". She denies substance use, maintains good physical health aside from requiring iron supplementation, and reports a childhood head injury at age 11 without loss of consciousness. Patient describes longstanding organizational tendencies dating back to approximately age 8, recalling precise block stacking and meticulous desk organization throughout her schooling. These behaviors were particularly pronounced during her high school years when her family sponsored relatives' citizenship, resulting in 16 people residing in her home. She demonstrates consistent contamination-related behaviors, including using barriers when touching public surfaces, frequent hand sanitization (predating the pandemic), and immediate cleaning of any perceived contamination. The patient engages in regular cleaning throughout the day, reporting an inability to tolerate "a single dirty dish in the sink" and an immediate need to address any uncleanliness she observes. Notably, she denies these behaviors cause distress or any impairment, stating she "enjoys" cleaning and maintaining organization. Patient reported persistent depressed mood, anhedonia, restlessness, fatigue, and feelings of worthlessness over the past two weeks, but said that these symptoms are manageable. She denies current or past suicidal ideation. While she denies feeling "up", "high", or "hyper", she describes persistent irritability manifesting as social withdrawal and increased argumentativeness, characterizing herself as "more lucid" than others because she doesn't "follow the script". She denies symptoms consistent with mania or hypomania, including grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, pressured speech, racing thoughts, distractibility, or increased goal-directed activity. The patient acknowledges experiencing an unspecified "extremely traumatic event" but denies re-experiencing it in distressing ways. Assessment ruled out panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, substance use disorders, psychotic disorders, eating disorders, and generalized anxiety disorder.

diagnosis: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (F42.2); Major Depressive Disorder (moderate, recurrent) (F33.1); Social Anxiety Disorder (F40.10); Excoriation Disorder (F42.4); Other Specified Eating Disorder: bulimia nervosa (of low frequency and limited duration) (F50.89)
case: Patient is a 24-year-old gender fluid individual with a BA in creative writing and sociology who is currently living with their parents while taking courses part-time and seeking employment. They describe their living situation as "overwhelming" due to parental boundary issues, though they maintain a supportive romantic relationship since 2019. Their psychiatric history includes diagnoses of MDD and GAD at age 15-16, PTSD in 2016 following emotional abuse by high school friends, and ADHD in 2018 (without neuropsychological evaluation). Current medications include Lisdexamfetamine 50mg (since 2018), various supplements, and a contraceptive injection. They previously tried multiple antidepressants (2011-2015) but discontinued each after approximately two weeks due to suicidal ideation and, in one case, motor disturbances. The patient consumes alcohol socially (3-5 drinks monthly) and has been vaping marijuana 1-3 times weekly for three months primarily to aid sleep and manage anxiety. The patient's primary symptoms onset around age 5 with intrusive visualizations of falling down stairs along with perfectionism through rewriting notes until they felt "just right". Currently, they experience significant distress when surroundings are not in the "right spot", spending up to 12 hours reorganizing belongings without breaks, which would cause severe distress if interrupted. This "not just right" feeling impairs their ability to meet deadlines, complete job applications, and fulfill social obligations. They also engage in checking behaviors when packing (counting socks repeatedly, checking for essential items) and experience distressing sexual intrusive thoughts. Additionally, the patient exhibits skin-picking behaviors, spending over an hour picking at ingrown hairs until bleeding, scratching their neck and jaw during conversations, and tearing at cuticles, with symptoms worsening during periods of anxiety. They've attempted to stop by wearing pants constantly but have been unsuccessful. The patient has a significant history of depression with three past suicide attempts (overdoses in 2014, 2015, and 2017) and self-injury through cutting (stopped in 2017). They currently experience passive suicidal ideation, anhedonia, decreased appetite, sleep difficulties, psychomotor agitation, feelings of worthlessness, and concentration problems, though they report 0% chance of self-harm in the next three months. Social anxiety manifests as persistent fear of judgment and rejection, with distressing rumination about social interactions and excessive reassurance-seeking that has cost them friendships. The patient also reported past sexual abuse by a boyfriend for 4-5 months but denied PTSD symptoms. They disclosed a history of binge eating episodes. During the binge, they ate more rapidly than normal and felt disgusted and embarrassed after. After these eating binges, pt fasted for ~3 days. These eating binges occurred <1 time per week, and the patient has not engaged in these behaviors in the past 2 months.

diagnosis: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (F42.2); Anorexia nervosa, restricting type, in partial remission (F50.014); Major depressive disorder, recurrent, in partial remission (F33.41)
case: The patient is an 18-year-old non-binary college freshman with a complex psychiatric presentation. They report a history of childhood anxiety, perfectionism, and ritualistic self-punishment behaviors starting in the third grade. Currently, their most debilitating symptom is anxiety about "contaminated air" when others cough or sneeze, prompting them to cover their face and hold their breath even when the trigger is far away or on television. They engage in checking and counting behaviors based on the number 3, including checking mirrors while driving, locking/unlocking their car, and tapping their toothbrush. These compulsions are experienced as uncontrollable, with the patient reporting they sometimes modify behaviors (like holding an imaginary door handle in their pocket) when the original compulsion would be disruptive. At approximately age 16, the patient developed anorexia nervosa, restricting their food intake and ultimately requiring intervention from parents and a treatment team. Despite gaining weight under external pressure, the patient continues to restrict eating, has a distinct fear of gaining weight, becoming fat, fasting until dinner, drinking coffee to intentionally upset their stomach. Their BMI currently falls within the normal range. Around the same time their eating disorder developed, the patient experienced depressive symptoms including hopelessness, low motivation, and self-harm behaviors (pulling hair, cutting, punching stomach). They had suicidal ideation during high school, including thoughts of jumping in front of a train and fantasizing about wandering into hallways during a school shooting. Current suicidal thoughts are less frequent and persistent. Current depressive symptoms have been subsyndromal (though not entirely absent) for about 7 months. Specifically, the patient currently denies experiencing depressive symptoms for more than a few hours every couple of weeks but rates their chance of self-harm in the next three months at 50% (suicide attempt chance at 0%). They report minimal alcohol and marijuana use. Notably, the patient expresses resistance to treatment, stating that "getting better means getting fat" and feeling they need to "stay sad for a while longer".

diagnosis: OCD, mild, fair insight, with panic (F42.2); Illness Anxiety Disorder (F45.21); Major Depressive Episode, recurrent, moderate (F33.1)
case: The patient is a 22-year-old female from the Southeastern United States with a history of Depression (2019), Anxiety (2019), and OCD (March 2021). She recently transitioned from working as a childcare specialist to self-employment as a freelancer. Her medical history includes anemia and IBS, for which she takes daily iron supplements. The patient previously attempted treatment with Zoloft (10mg) for OCD symptoms but discontinued due to emotional blunting effects. She reports consuming alcohol 1-2 glasses a few times monthly and using marijuana daily when available, which she finds helpful for intrusive thoughts despite occasionally triggering anxiety. The patient's most distressing symptoms involve intrusive thoughts about sexually harming children, accompanied by physiological responses that she describes as "groinal". These thoughts were particularly distressing during her work as a childcare specialist, where she engaged in compulsive staring at children's genital areas to "prove" she wasn't sexually attracted to them and sometimes avoided changing diapers due to fear of sexual arousal. After experiencing an intrusive dream about sexually harming her brother in January 2021, she experienced physical symptoms (shaking, freezing) when interacting with him and subsequently increased their time together as a form of reassurance. Additionally, the patient reports significant health anxiety focused on getting cancer, HIV, and STIs, leading to excessive symptom research. The patient experiences panic attacks (1-2 times monthly) lasting 15-30 minutes when triggered by intrusive thoughts, with symptoms including shortness of breath, crying, sweating, racing heart, chest pain, and feelings of detachment. She reports seeking reassurance from her mother when these thoughts become overwhelming. The patient also endorses distressing and functionally impairing social anxiety in small groups, leading to significant avoidance; however, she stated that this anxiety is primary due to her unwanted/intrusive thoughts rather than a fear of being judged. She reports experiencing over 50 depressive episodes in the past year, each lasting at least two weeks with symptoms including decreased appetite, sleep disturbance, fatigue, guilt, concentration difficulties, and thoughts of death. She described these episodes as challenging to manage, but "not completely debilitating".

diagnosis: Oppositional Defiant Disorder, Moderate (F91.3); Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder, Combined Type (F90.2)
case: Erik is a 10-year-old male who recently completed 4th grade in a gifted math program. He lives with his biological parents and seven-year-old brother, with whom he has "constant" conflict including arguing, screaming, and hitting. Erik has a developmental history of severe temper tantrums prior to age 4, with behavioral challenges emerging in kindergarten and worsening in subsequent grades. His mother reports that her son engages in "constant defiance", experiences rapid mood changes, and demonstrates impulsive behavior, including occasional incidents of pulling knives (though never pointing them at anyone). Daily arguments at home frequently escalate to physical aggression, particularly with his mother and brother. Erik has expressed statements such as "I wish I could go to sleep and never wake up" and reports feeling depressed "randomly" a couple times per month since second or third grade, though he denies daily depressive symptoms or changes in sleep or appetite. Erik's behavioral difficulties have manifested in both home and school environments. In school, he has engaged in speaking out of turn, refusing to follow directions, agitating teachers, and having "screaming matches" with staff. Despite these challenges, Erik maintains high grades across subjects (with math being his most difficult class at a B), has several friends, and is described as a leader in social interactions. He has a Section 504 plan that allows for movement opportunities and frequent breaks when needed. In March 2019, Erik began taking 2mg of Guanfacine (extended release) for attention/concentration deficits, which has helped reduce impulsivity and improve behavioral control, though aggressive and defiant behaviors have continued. His mother reports implementing a point system for rewards and consequences but notes limited effectiveness due to inconsistent expectations between parents. Formal assessment indicates that Erik demonstrates a pattern of emotional dysregulation, defiance, and aggressive behavior, with physical aggression occurring approximately every other day at home. Assessment also confirms prior symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, which are present across settings and contribute to emotional dysregulation and academic underperformance relative to ability.

diagnosis: Schizophrenia, Multiple Episodes, Currently in Acute Episode (F20.9); Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, Poor Insight (F42.2)
case: Dole is a 31-year-old male who arrived for intake with an extensive psychiatric history dating back to age 17, with multiple hospitalizations and diagnoses including Mood Disorder NOS, Bipolar Disorder, Narcissistic Personality Disorder, Schizoaffective Disorder, and Asperger's Syndrome. His symptoms have included paranoid ideation, auditory and visual hallucinations, delusions (such as believing television was sending special messages), obsessive thoughts, compulsive behaviors, and periods of mania and depression. Dole holds a master’s degree in computer science and previously developed cybersecurity systems but resigned in 2019 due to unmanageable anxiety. He currently lives with his parents, who provide significant assistance with daily activities. Throughout his treatment history, Dole has demonstrated paranoid thoughts beginning at age 19, with recurrent episodes of acute psychosis requiring hospitalization. In 2018, he experienced hallucinations of messages on his phone, and in 2019, he reported seeing "the devil" and experiencing auditory hallucinations. He endorses unwanted/intrusive thoughts causing anxiety, which he attempts to neutralize with repetitive behaviors that take 1-3 hours daily. His symptoms include fear of harming himself, violent imagery, concerns about germs, and moral preoccupations. Dole reports deficits in procedural and episodic memory, impairing self-care and accurate recollection of past events. His family history is positive for paternal psychosis, depression with possible bipolar disorder, and a completed suicide. Intake impressions indicate that Dole has experienced (and continues to experience) delusions, hallucinations, disorganized/catatonic behavior, diminished emotional expression, and amotivation within a one-month period. He has exhibited delusions or hallucinations for at least two weeks in the absence of major mood episodes, and his functioning has decreased notably compared to his pre-symptom baseline. Regarding his unwanted/intrusive thoughts, he demonstrates limited insight.

diagnosis: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, Poor Insight, with Panic (F42.2); Other Specified Depressive Disorder (Insufficient Symptoms for MDD) (F32.89)
case: Patient is a 32-year-old Black American male with no prior diagnostic history who presents with a chief complaint of "uncontrollable staring, particularly at breasts/genitals". The patient reports that this behavior began at age 27 (late 2017) and involves involuntary staring at people he does not know well, with particular focus on the genitals/breasts of all genders and ages, including children. He spends approximately six hours per day engaged in or thinking about this behavior, which he cannot control through willpower alone, though he can interrupt it by creating a physical barrier in his line of sight or wearing sunglasses. The patient initially denied but later acknowledged experiencing unwanted sexual thoughts regarding his sexual orientation. This behavior has significantly impaired his functioning, causing him to lose multiple jobs within the past year, avoid family gatherings, limit time in public, and experience relationship strain with his girlfriend of 12 years, with whom he has three children and now stays home while she works. The patient experiences moderate suicidal ideation, including thoughts that he would be better off dead, and reports feeling worthless and guilty, particularly about "not providing for my children and for staring". He describes his mood as "iffy" and notes increased irritability. While the patient endorsed panic attacks on assessment, follow-up questioning revealed these occur specifically when thinking excessively about his staring behaviors or unemployment, rather than occurring spontaneously. He also endorsed criteria for agoraphobia and social anxiety on screening, though these appear directly related to fears of being judged for his staring behavior. The patient acknowledged witnessing a traumatic event he chose not to disclose but denied re-experiencing or avoidance symptoms consistent with PTSD. Medical history includes hypertension treated with Amlodipine (dose unknown), with no psychiatric medication history reported.Throughout the assessment, the patient demonstrated limited insight into his symptoms, was guarded in his responses, and had not disclosed his problems to his long-term partner. While he reported some depressive symptoms, these did not meet sufficient symptoms for major depressive disorder but were nonetheless clinically significant.

diagnosis: Other psychoactive substance abuse with psychoactive substance-induced psychotic disorder with delusions (F19.150)
case: A 32-year-old male with a past medical history of polysubstance use disorder (cocaine, marijuana, and methamphetamine) presents for bizarre behavior brought in by emergency medical services (EMS) after a neighbor called to report that patient was outside her home threatening her with a knife. Per neighbor's report, the patient had been yelling about the FBI and demanding to be let into her home while waving a knife. Patient was yelling at paramedics enroute and attempted to punch a paramedic when being loaded into the ambulance. Upon arrival to the emergency room, patient was agitated, requiring emergency intermuscular injection of medications to deescalate. Patient told doctors in the emergency room that he felt unsafe and needed them to watch his knives for him. He felt like the government was going to come get him and use the weapons in his home against him. He recalls going to the neighbor's home in an attempt to have her hide his knives for him. A few hours later, the psychiatry team came to evaluate the patient, at which point the patient appeared drowsy and asked to be left alone due to feeling tired. He refused to provide urine sample but allowed a blood draw. His blood work returned with elevated white blood count (WBC) at 18 x10e3/uL. He denied having any prior psychiatric diagnoses but admitted that he has been using methamphetamine recently. He recalls he had been admitted to an inpatient psychiatry service before, around 1 year prior after using meth, where he stayed for 3 days and was discharged on Seroquel, which patient denied currently taking. He does not recall his diagnosis from that admission. Patient agreed to receive further care at a psychiatric facility and was voluntarily transferred to an inpatient psychiatry unit. Patient was started again on Seroquel but refused to take it during admission. He was seen napping during the day and reported some stomach cramping to the treatment team. By day 3 of admission, patient reported feeling well and signed himself out of the hospital.
diagnosis_icd: Other psychoactive substance abuse with psychoactive substance-induced psychotic disorder with delusions (F19.150)
reasoning: Patient only has known history of 1 prior episode of psychosis, which appeared to be in the setting of substance use (meth). Patient this time also admitted to using meth recently. While urine sample was not obtained, an elevated WBC can be indicative of methamphetamine use in the absence of infection. Additionally, fatigue and gastrointestinal upset are common symptoms of stimulant withdrawal. Resolution of symptoms in a short course of only 3 days and without medication is another evidence for substance-induced psychosis rather than a primary psychotic disorder. However, with such limited history, an underlying primary psychotic disorder cannot be fully ruled out and thus antipsychotic treatment may still be indicated.

diagnosis: Major depressive disorder, severe, with psychosis (F32.3); Cannabis dependence (F12.20); Xanax use disorder, severe, with dependence (F13.232)
case: A 16-year-old male in the 9th grade with no known past psychiatric history presented as a walk-in admission to the county psychiatric hospital with his mother. He started seeing a therapist recently after mom noticed that he was talking to her less and appeared less energetic. Mom reports that the patient has also been behaving oddly, accusing downstairs neighbors to be trying to spy on him and talking poorly about him. She also reports that he told her he feels unsafe because people are trying to harm him. She also noticed that he has been more irritable, occasionally punching walls but never people. When patient was interviewed directly, he appeared constricted and dysphoric, with hair covering his eyes. He spoke softly. He reported that he has been feeling angry because he has been thinking more about how his biological father used to abuse his mom, even though his biological father no longer is in their life. He reports that he has been experiencing poor memory, poor concentration, feeling anxious and ruminating frequently. He also admits to having thoughts of death several months ago and does have access to guns although he has never attempted to kill himself. He does report that he intentionally cut his wrist a few months ago to cope with his feelings but denied having suicidal intent. He also endorses poor sleep and low mood. He admits that he is a long-time bars user (referring to Xanax) but does not know the dosage and is evasive when asked about his frequency and most recent use. He also reports that he smokes marijuana but again does not provide details regarding his use. He states that more recently, he started using marijuana specifically to help with new-onset paranoia. He describes his mind playing tricks on him, morphing objects into faces leading to feeling scared. Lab work collected at the hospital did not show abnormalities other than a positive urine cannabinoid screen. Patient was started on fluoxetine for his depression symptoms and aripiprazole for his psychotic symptoms and he improved after a week on this medication combination, reporting better mood and no longer feeling paranoid.
diagnosis_dsm: Major depressive disorder, severe, with psychosis
diagnosis_icd: Major depressive disorder, severe, with psychosis (F32.3); Cannabis dependence (F12.20); Xanax use disorder, severe, with dependence (F13.232)
reasoning: Patient appears to have both symptoms of depression and psychosis. However, since it appears that the depressive symptoms appeared first (several months ago) with the psychotic features appearing later on with the severity of depression (more recently, new-onset), the diagnosis would be MDD with psychosis rather than a primary psychotic disorder such as schizoaffective disorder. The patient also has demonstrated cannabis use and Xanax dependency.

diagnosis: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (F42)
case: A 14-year-old male patient with a history of generalized anxiety disorder is brought to his pediatrician for a skin exam after she saw the patient wiping his skin down with a Clorox wipe. She reports that since the start of COVID in 2020, patient has been more vigilant about keeping his space and belongings clean, wiping down his devices upon returning from any outing, wiping down doorknobs, light switches, and bathroom counters daily. She states that initially, he feared catching COVID. However, she states it has been 3 years of such behaviors and believes that his cleaning behaviors have actually intensified. She noticed that he started washing his hands more often, sometimes showering multiple times in a day, and last week, saw him use a Clorox disinfecting wipe to clean his body. She became concerned for the potential of chemical irritation on his skin. When patient was addressed directly, patient reports that he needs everything to be clean. He expresses an intense fear that his belongings and space are contaminated with germs if he does not clean then regularly. He alludes to his view of the outside as “dirty” and that his room is “clean.” He feels the intense urge to have anything that enters his room to be decontaminated otherwise his whole room will become contaminated. He describes an intense feeling of anxiety if he cannot clean things before they enter his room. He states that he spends a lot of time washing his hands because if he misses a spot or brushes his hand against the side of the sink, he needs to start over to ensure that they are fully clean. He endorses similar patterns with showering and wiping down belongings, often needing to start over to ensure he did not miss any spots and has fully decontaminated. He does mention that he has been struggling in school due to having less time to study with his cleaning obligations.
diagnosis_icd: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (F42)

diagnosis: Borderline personality disorder (F60.3)
case: Patient is a 23-year-old male patient with a past psychiatric history of anxiety and depression who is hospitalized for a suicide attempt 2 days ago during a fight with his girlfriend. He reports that he took a handful of pills (escitalopram) that he has prescribed for anxiety. He reports that 2 days ago, his girlfriend was angry at him and suggested that she was thinking about leaving the relationship. The patient reports that he felt very hurt and wanted to show her how much he was hurt by her statement, which is why he took the pills. He described the act as impulsive and wasn’t sure if he truly wanted to die in the moment. He states that he does not regret his decision but also denies any suicidal ideation (SI) currently. He also denies feeling depressed prior to the fight. He states that his friends and loved ones “always” leave him and that he was hurt because he thought his girlfriend was different. When asked about outpatient care, he expressed a mistrust for mental health providers, stating that most of them “just don’t get it” and that he is still working on finding a therapist who understands him. He says that the last clinic assigned him a female provider even though he requested a male provider. He admits that they stated they didn’t have any male providers available at the time, but still feels that they betrayed him by making him false promises. He endorses feeling like he isn’t worth other people’s time and feeling depressed often, especially when relationships or friendships don’t work out. He denies recent insomnia, appetite changes, concentration or memory issues, and anhedonia. He is seen to have multiple healed lacerations on bilateral forearms, which he states are scars from cutting. He asks the provider if they think he may have bipolar disorder or autism because he feels like he gets “mood swings” and has difficulty in keeping friends. However, his mania screen was negative, and he has no history of social, speech, or learning delays in childhood that may have indicated autism.
diagnosis_icd: Borderline personality disorder (F60.3)
reasoning: Patient has a pattern of pervasive instability in his interpersonal relationships (difficulty in maintaining long-term friendships or relationships), unstable emotions (endorsed mood swings), and marked impulsivity (impulsively overdosed). He also demonstrates a fear of abandonment (threat of a breakup is what triggered this episode) and feeling that people “always leave” him. This suicide attempt is not secondary to major depressive disorder (MDD) as he does not have the criteria for MDD of >2 weeks of low/depressed mood or anhedonia.

diagnosis: Narcissistic personality disorder (F60.81)
case: Patient is a 31-year-old female denying any psychiatric history who was transferred to the county psychiatry hospital from a local emergency room for threatening to kill herself. She tells the evaluating psychiatrist that she had gotten into an argument with her husband. She states that she and her husband has been living in a hotel for the past week due to a conflict between her and her mother-in-law. She reports that she feels her husband does not understand nor respect her because he was requesting to return home to be closer to his workplace. She states that she was surprised at the argument because he is usually a “good man.” When asked what made her feel disrespected this time, she replied it was because he was refusing her request to continue staying at the hotel and that he usually never says no to her. When asked her reason for staying, she stated that she just “did not feel ready” to return home yet because being around her mother-in-law stressed her out. She did not understand why her husband was not accommodating her discomfort. However, when pointing out husband’s discomfort with the long commute time to work, she minimized his concern and did not acknowledge his struggle, instead redirecting the conversation to her own feelings. When asked about the reason for her disagreement with her mother-in-law, she states it is because her mother-in-law does not recognize her efforts for contributing to the household. She states that, “My mother-in-law always complains that I don’t do chores and don’t work. But she doesn’t get it that I’m the one supporting my husband at his job and that he should be the main breadwinner anyways as the husband. Besides, I did the dishes today, it’s not even true that I don’t do chores.” When addressing the physicians, she addresses them casually (e.g. “dude,” “man,” etc.) and states to them, “You’re a doctor, you should be smart enough to understand me.” She denies that she has any mental issues that requires her to remain in the hospital, stating that, “Smart people like us, we get misunderstood, you get it right? That’s why they sent me here.” She also alludes to believing that her mother-in-law called the police to have her brought here to get her away from her husband because she’s “jealous I get to spend more time with her son than she does.” When informing her that the reason for her hospitalization was the threat of suicide, she casually waves it off, stating, “Oh, I don’t actually want to kill myself, I just said that to get my husband to listen to me.”
diagnosis_icd: Narcissistic personality disorder (F60.81)
reasoning: Patient demonstrates an expectation to be recognized as superior (like with her mother-in-law), feeling that they are special and can only be understood by smart people like doctors, exploitative behaviors of expecting her husband to go along with her every demand and attempting to manipulate him via suicidal threats when he does not comply, a lack of empathy towards her husband, and believing that her mother-in-law is envious of her. These traits are key features for narcissistic personality disorder.

diagnosis: Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (F90.9)
case: Patient is a 6-year-old patient presenting to a first-time psychiatric appointment at the request of the school. The patient just started in kindergarten 5 months ago. Teachers have called parents multiple times for being disruptive in class, being loud, getting up when he isn’t supposed to, and frequently interrupting teachers and other classmates. His parents say that he has never had any psychiatric diagnoses before, and they didn’t think anyone in the family has any problems either. He has a good number of friends and doesn’t struggle socially. At home, mom reports that he does like to do active things like play tag, ride his bike, and learn how to play soccer. In clinic, he gets up frequently to look at things in the office, playing with hand sanitizer dispenser, and tries to get mom’s attention when the psychiatrist is speaking with her.
diagnosis_icd: Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (F90.9)

diagnosis: Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (F34.81)
case: Patient is a 10-year-old female who is brought into the walk-in area of a psychiatric hospital for hitting kids at school. The patient is a ward of the state, both of her parents were found to be unfit to care for the child. The guardian received a report from her teacher that the patient slapped a classmate during an argument. The patient is in the 5th grade. She has had many other reports this year for throwing tantrums and getting into fights. Guardian reports that patient has a history of being returned from various foster and adoptive families due to anger and aggression. She states that since the patient has been under her care, she has noticed the patient to be easily irritable with little to no accountability for her own actions, blaming the other kids for annoying her or saying that “I didn’t mean it.” Aggressive outbursts occur multiple times a week. When asked, the patient says that other kids annoy her but is unable to specify examples. She also says that staff and teachers annoy her too. However, she denies hitting them. The patient during the assessment repeated interrupts the guardian and the evaluator saying, “I didn’t do anything,” and begging to be taken home. As guardian shares reports made by the school, the patient interrupts and calls guardian a “liar” and is visibly upset. Patient begs the evaluator to let her go home and not recommend hospitalization. However, when evaluator informed patient that aggression is often a reason for admission, patient suddenly becomes very angry, picking up a tissues box and throwing it at the glass divider between her and the evaluator. When evaluator pointed out her behavior, patient immediately becomes tearful and apologetic, stating,” I didn’t do anything, I didn’t mean it, I didn’t even hit you.” Guardian states that behaviors like this is what she is referring to. Guardian reports that her outbursts are most common when she doesn’t get her way, but that she seems to be irritable in general as well.
diagnosis_icd: Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (F34.81)
reasoning: The patient has outbursts that demonstrate poor emotional regulation. She is described as irritable even between outbursts and symptoms started before the age of 10. She has multiple episodes per week. Her outbursts are against both authority figures and peers which makes diagnosis DMDD rather than ODD.

diagnosis: Oppositional defiant disorder (F91.3)
case: The patient is a 12-year-old male who is brought to clinic by his mom due to multiple detentions for his behavior. Per the school report, patient does not follow instructions in class, becomes argumentative with teachers, and is disrespectful, often using profanities against his teachers and staff. Mom states that he has started doing the same at home as well, refusing to do his chores, arguing with her when she tells him to do his homework, and mocks her when she confronts him. She notes that in addition to refusal to do chores, he will intentionally create more chores to do, such as making messes and not cleaning them up. When asked directly about his behaviors, the patient looks at the evaluator and rolls his eyes. He tells the evaluator that it’s “none of your business” and kicks the desk. When asked if there is anything in his life causing stress that may be causing him to ask out, he states, “yea, my mom.” He denies any depression or suicidal ideation.
diagnosis_icd: Oppositional defiant disorder (F91.3)
