diagnosis: Major depressive disorder, single episode, unspecified (F32.9)
case: The patient is a 15-year-old male who is brought to the clinic by his grandmother for being irritable and angry at home. She reports that for the past few months, he has been spending more time alone in his room, will lash out when asked to come spend time with family, and has been spending less time with his friends. His grades have dropped in school, and he says it’s because school is “stupid and pointless.” When asked why he thinks so, he says it’s because he’s not going to amount to anything anyways. He appears tired and said he has been spending more time napping because of boredom. His grandmother asks him about his games that he likes to play, but he says he’d rather just sleep, the games are boring. He tells the evaluator that he thinks it’s dumb that she even brought him here because it’s a waste of everyone’s time. Grandmother says he has never acted like this before, and that he used to be a bright boy with a lot of friends.
diagnosis_dsm: Major depressive disorder single episode, unspecified
diagnosis_icd: Major depressive disorder, single episode, unspecified (F32.9)
reasoning: MDD in adolescents and children can often present as irritability rather than clear depression. He does have anhedonia as evidenced by him saying his games are boring, hypersomnia, concentration/memory issues evidenced by grades dropping, feelings of hopelessness evidenced by thinking he won’t amount to anything, and feeling like a burden evidenced by thinking being cared for is a waste of everyone’s time.

diagnosis: Bipolar disorder, current manic without psychotic features (F31.1)
case: Patient is a 23-year-old college male student who presents to the emergency room after fighting with a classmate, leading to a physical altercation. He smells like marijuana and eyes are bloodshot. The girlfriend of the patient, who was a witness to the fight, is present and tells the ER staff that the patient was making accusations to the classmate that he was a “demon sent from Hell” to make everyone fail their finals. He made claims that “I am the Messiah” and “I was sent to stop him.” He claims that he is the best student the college has ever seen, in fact he is going to be the president after he graduates. He tells the staff that he wants to start campaigning here in the hospital and that he will use “the Gospel” to lead America to greatness. Psychiatry is consulted and collateral information gathered from the girlfriend revealed that the patient has acted oddly before but has not gotten aggressive until this incident. She recalls a few months ago when the patient was equally energetic and telling her of his plans to become the new Dean of the school. He would stay up late making plans and spent his entire monthly allowance that week on gifts for her. She wasn’t sure if he slept much at all for that week before eventually crashing and sleeping for half a day at the end of that week. She notes that he also started smoking marijuana a couple weeks ago at the behest of their friend but had never used prior to her knowledge.
diagnosis_dsm: Bipolar disorder, current manic without psychotic features
diagnosis_icd: Bipolar disorder, current manic without psychotic features (F31.1)

diagnosis: Major depressive disorder, single episode, severe without psychotic features (F32.2)
case: Pt is a 20-year-old female with no past psychiatric history came to the clinic seeking help for depression and having passive thoughts of death. She says her mother passed away 2 months back. She reports feeling increasingly depressed since loss of mom, has been crying tearful while talking to the outpatient psychiatrist. She reported she was at work, came back and she found her mom lying in the pool of blood. She reports that her mother committed suicide. She reports she has been having increased nightmares. She has been feeling increasingly depressed for the past 2 months, has problems with appetite, is not going to work, likes to just stay at home as feels mom's presence in the house. She has been mostly staying at home except for some long walks at night at times, lost weight, cannot focus. Her friends provide her support during the difficult time and bring her food and clean her house for her. She has been feeling guilty for ignoring mom while she was going through the depression. She should have been more supportive of her and maybe could have saved her mom. This has been making her feel it was all her fault and that she should be dead too and not live anymore but does not have a plan or an intention to die. She reports having trouble sleeping at night, sleeping approximately 2-3 hours every night, going out for a walk when not sleeping. She has been engaging in increased promiscuous behaviors like having one-night stands with the people she meets on the walks. She reports her energy is okay the next day and has not slept in for about a month. She denied any past medical problems and denied any substance use. She has a history of sexual abuse in the past at age 18.
diagnosis_dsm: Major depressive Disorder, single, severe, with mixed features
diagnosis_icd: Major depressive disorder, single episode, severe without psychotic features (F32.2)

diagnosis: Bipolar disorder I, current episode manic with psychotic symptoms (F31.2); Catatonic disorder due to known physiological condition (F06.1)
case: Pt is a 25-year-old female who came was admitted involuntarily to an inpatient psychiatric unit for altered mental status. She is seen to make bizarre movements where she is falling back and rolling on the ground was reported to have not eaten much in the last 4- 5 days and has been just sitting at one spot for most of the day. She minimally engages with you. She was given Lorazepam 2 mg intramuscularly which was helpful to calm her down and she was able to talk more to the team. She reports history of depression and was started on Sertraline 50 mg PO daily. She was compliant to these medications for the past 3 months. She reports she lost her mother with the battle with cancer 3 months ago. She was missing her mom, started to feel depressed, stopped eating much after her death, had problems with sleep, felt hopeless and sometimes would struggle to get through the day with no energy at all. Once, she was started on Sertraline she noticed improvement in her symptoms for the past month. A friend who brought her to the hospital reported for the past week, patient is unable to sleep and has been cleaning her house vivaciously at night, has been going out for walks for 3 hours, has been feeling great with her energy for the past week. She reports patient went out and bought herself a brand-new Mercedes. She is unsure if patient had that much money in her account. She noticed patient just crashing down, feeling more confused since past 2 days where she was mostly altered. Friend reports “she was not making any sense in what she says” and she brought her to the hospital. Her labs showed mild elevation in BUN, creatinine was normal, liver function tests were normal, WBC count normal, low hemoglobin of 10.1 with MCV of 70. Urine drug screen and pregnancy test was negative. Friend reports no other past medical problems or any allergies. She denied any history of substance use.
diagnosis_dsm: Bipolar disorder I, most recent episode manic with psychotic symptoms with catatonia
diagnosis_icd: Bipolar disorder I, current episode manic with psychotic symptoms (F31.2); Catatonic disorder due to known physiological condition (F06.1)

diagnosis: Adjustment disorder with anxiety (F43.2)
case: Pt is a 19-year-old female who presented to the student health clinic at her university with increase in anxiety symptoms that started since last 3 months at the beginning of the school year. She reports her main concern is she will not be successful and will not be able to make the grades she needs to get a medical school. She feels anxious most of the days. She says her heart rate goes up, she starts to sweat, with racing thoughts and having problems with sleep. She notices she is unable to breathe, gets nauseous at times when it is very bad anxiety. When a teacher calls on her in school, she becomes “frozen with fear” if she will say something ill-informed or inappropriate. She has hard time engaging with other peers at college. She also reports feeling anxious about if she will ever be able to make friends with his anxiety. She gets panic attacks at times where she describes she has racing thoughts of what is everyone thinking or maybe they are laughing at her or talking about her. She starts to breath heavily, feels numb but does not feel she will die. Her attacks are usually triggered when she must present in front of her classmates. This makes her anxious to the point of getting paralyzed and cannot concentrate on her work. When she goes back home, she can do better. She is calmer and can enjoy time with friends and family. She goes out of walks and laughs and spends time with her loved ones. She tells her friend she feels lonely in college and does not have many friends and always under stress to do better. She is obsessive about “doing better” and compulsive about “studying” but denied any intrusive thoughts. She denied any medical problems, denied any allergies and history of substance use. She denied any past psychiatric history of being diagnosed with any illness or being on medications. She aspires to become a physician one day and able to help others.
diagnosis_icd: Adjustment disorder with anxiety (F43.2)

diagnosis: Schizophreniform Disorder (F20.81)
case: Pt is a 25-year-old male with past psychiatric history of depression diagnosed 3 months ago came in here for increased voices and feeling paranoid. He reports he has been hearing voices for the past one month which tell him multiple things. Some of the voices are “good” voices that tell him to take care of himself while others are “bad” telling him to hurt himself at times. He says 3 weeks ago; he was admitted to a hospital because he drank bleach secondary to voices telling him to do so. He reports feeling paranoid that someone will come and hurt him. He thinks some enemies can hear him through the vents at home and can know what he is thinking. He is scared for his life and tells his parents he wants to kill these people but does not know where they live. He gets scared to the point he is not sleeping for multiple days and looking for these men in the attic and different parts of his house. He reports on and off poor sleep but for the past 2-3 days before admission he was unable to sleep much. His appetite has been low and cannot focus. He feels sad and depressed about all these people coming after him. He reports since these people started to follow him, he has been feeling sadder and more depressed. He denied any suicidal ideations. His mom describes him mostly staying in his room, does not take shower many times, must be encouraged or forced sometimes to take shower. He stopped talking to his friends, likes to stay on his own now. She feels he is not motivated to do anything around him. She reports six months back he was helping her with house chores, had a job distributing papers in the neighborhood. He denied any medical problems. He denied any allergies to medications, has family history of maternal grandmother diagnosed with Schizophrenia. He reports he was started on Sertraline 50 mg daily for depression without much benefit. His symptoms are getting worse by the day. He denied any substance use problems.
diagnosis_icd: Schizophreniform Disorder (F20.81)

diagnosis: Other psychoactive substance related disorders (F19)
case: Pt is a 42-year-old female who came into the emergency room reporting auditory hallucinations for a day that have been telling her to hurt herself. She reports she is not from the city and is traveling for her work. She reports she has past psychiatric history of depression three years back and reports she has been off medications and her symptoms have been well controlled. She started feeling sad now that she is hearing voices, and they are telling her to kill herself and she is worried for her safety. She talked to her mom on the phone and mom asked her to call 911 so she can go the emergency room. She has been staying at the hotel for the past one day. She planned to go to her work for the next couple of days and wanted to look for houses to move to this new city. On admission to the emergency room, she is seen to be very scared, thinks she is in her hometown and that the year currently was her birth year. She was not oriented to time and place. Her blood pressure is 150/90, pulse 110, temp of 98.6, saturation 97 %. She is scared someone will come and hurt her and she will not be able to see her mom again and is often seen to scream her name. She was given Ativan 2 mg intramuscularly along with Haldol 5 mg and Benadryl 50 mg intramuscularly to help calm her down. Emergency contact, her mother was contacted. She reports patient having history of alcohol withdrawal seizures, last seizures were three years ago. She says she has been sober for three years except recently due to stress of work she started to drink more with last drink three days ago. She denied any drug use/ tobacco use. Mom reports she saw her more anxious and stressed out for the past 4-5 days due to work and family stressors. She reports she seemed depressed, was not eating much, just working, sleep was okay, was hopeful her move to the new city will be better for her stress and she will be able to thrive better. She denied any medical problems.
diagnosis_icd: Other psychoactive substance related disorders (F19)

diagnosis: Separation anxiety disorder (F93.0)
case: Pt is a 15-year-old boy was brought in by his parents to a psychiatric outpatient clinic for the main complaints of anxiety. Mom reports he has been feeling increasingly anxious since last seven months since his friend’s mom passed away. He has been feeling increasingly anxious when his mom goes to work, or he must go to school. He starts to feel she will have an accident, and he will lose her or something bad might happen to her. He remains thinking of the different scenarios throughout the day as if his mind does not shut off. He reports having racing thoughts of whatever and however bad situation might be. He is unable to focus on school and his grades are declining. His teachers complain he has not been submitting his assignments in time. His friends at school have drifted away from him. He has started to feel lonelier at school. He reports his sleep has been bad, multiple times he has been having nightmares of mom leaving him and going away. He denied any auditory hallucinations, denied any visual hallucinations. He wants to live more and wants to spend more time with his mom. When he is at home, he loves to spend time with his mom and loves to help her in kitchen and do chores in the house. He denied any substance use, denied any medical problems or allergies.
diagnosis_icd: Separation anxiety disorder (F93.0)

diagnosis: Other encephalitis and encephalomyelitis (G04.81)
case: Patient A is a 27 year old female with no past medical or psychiatric history who presents after 2 days of new-onset paranoia. Two days ago, her husband states that the patient began speaking about her concerns that the neighbors were watching her and that they were out to get her. He also notes that it appears she was hallucinating and internally preoccupied. He states the patient has never done this in the past. On the exam, her thought process is illogical and disorganized, she appears to be responding to internal stimuli. She speaks about being concerned that people are out to get her and that she is worried about her safety. Lab work with CBC, CMP, UDS, UA, thyroid panel, B12, folate, HIV, syphilis are unremarkable. Psychiatry is consulted and starts her on a low dose of Seroquel. After one dose, the patient begins to have worsening psychotic symptoms and an acute dystonic reaction. Benadryl is given for acute dystonia and Seroquel is stopped. CT Head imaging is unremarkable. Suddenly, patient begins having a seizure and is admitted for further work up. EEG shows epileptiform discharges. CT A/P is done; there is suspicion for an ovarian teratoma which is confirmed with abdominal ultrasound. Neurology is consulted, LP is completed and CSF study for anti-NMDA antibody is positive. Pt is admitted to the Neurology service for PLEX.
diagnosis_icd: Other encephalitis and encephalomyelitis (G04.81)

diagnosis: Adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depression (F42.23)
case: Patient B is a 60 year old male with past medical history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes, newly diagnosed prostate cancer and a past psychiatric history of anxiety who was admitted to the hospital for cancer treatment. Psychiatry is consulted for depression. The patient has been hospitalized for 7 days now, and the course has been complicated by a DVT. On assessment, the pt appears dysphoric with a constricted affect. He shares that being in the hospital and receiving this new cancer diagnosis has caused a major disruption in his life. Previously, he was still working as a patent lawyer and running his own law firm. He states that since the diagnosis (which he received 1 month ago), his mood has been more depressed with anhedonia, hopelessness, helplessness, low energy, and low appetite which he attributes to the nausea caused by his chemotherapy. He feels constantly worried about his cancer and what will happen to him and his family. The patient is married to his wife for 30 years and has 2 children with 4 grandchildren. He is concerned about the finances, getting his estate planning in order, and worried about what will happen to his wife if he were to pass. He states prior to receiving this diagnosis, he did not have any difficulties with depression. He had a distant history of anxiety when he was in law school, but he states it has since been better controlled with therapy. He has never taken psychiatric medication and never seen a psychiatrist.
diagnosis_dsm: Adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depression
diagnosis_icd: Adjustment disorder with mixed anxiety and depression (F42.23)

diagnosis: Schizophrenia, unspecified (F20.9)
case: Patient C is a 24 year old male with no past medical or psychiatric history who presents to an inpatient psychiatric hospital after his family filed an emergency detention order to have him hospitalized due to psychosis. The family state the patient has been steadily declining over the past 2 years. They share he was a high-achieving college student and graduated with a degree in electrical engineering. In the past 2 years, he has become more withdrawn, appears more depressed, and his hygiene has declined to the point where he no longer showers. He lost his job due to the fact he was unable to keep up with his duties. In the past 6 months, they’ve noticed the patient’s speech start to become rambled and illogical. They state “it looks like he’s talking to someone not there”. Family history is significant for schizophrenia in the patient’s paternal grandfather. On assessment with the patient, he appears internally preoccupied, withdrawn, and is difficult to engage. His speech is illogical, disorganized, and with increased latency. He is noted to be malodorous with poor hygiene. Lab work-up with CBC, CMP, thyroid panel, HIV, Syphilis, B12, and folate are negative. UDS is positive for marijuana. He is started on Risperidone. After 5 days on the medication, he is less internally preoccupied, able to state he was hearing voices that are still present, but less loud and comprehensible. However, his affect still is flat and he is still mostly withdrawn to his room. His hygiene has improved and he was able to take a shower.
diagnosis_icd: Schizophrenia, unspecified (F20.9)

diagnosis: Conduct disorder, adolescent-onset type (F91.1); Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (F34.81)
case: Patient D is a 16-year-old male with no past medical history and a past psychiatric history of DMDD and ODD who presents to the psychiatric ER after he assaulted his mother. He was brought in accompanied by police officers. The patient was calm, at times defiant towards the physician. When asked what happened, the patient explains that his mother had told him to clean his room, and he did not want to. He was playing video games and did not want to stop. His mother asked again, and he again ignored her. She attempted to take away his video game and, in the process, the patient punched her in the head. He states, “she was being a bitch”. The patient has a history of truancy of school and currently has pending charges for assaulting another student at school starting at age 14. Mother provides collateral history that pt endured sexual abuse at a young age by his biological father who is now in prison. She states that the patient has a problem with authority figures, frequently arguing with her and teachers. She states he will often skip school and run away from home. She mentions he seems “irritable all the time” and when he is told to do something he doesn’t want to, he “explodes”, this started at age 9 and has been on-going. Mother notes that his siblings fear him and shares that the patient frequently hits their household dog, sometimes “too hard”. UDS is positive for marijuana, pt admits to smoking marijuana daily for 1 year.
diagnosis_dsm: Conduct disorder, Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder
diagnosis_icd: Conduct disorder, adolescent-onset type (F91.1); Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (F34.81)

diagnosis: Bipolar disorder with current depressed episode (F31.3)
case: Patient E is 25 year old female with past psychiatric history of anxiety and depression who presents to her PCP appointment for an annual follow-up. The PCP conducts a depression screening and patient endorses depressed mood, anhedonia, hopelessness, low energy, difficulty concentrating, and feelings of guilt/worthlessness. She states she has felt like this for most of the day, nearly every day for about 3 weeks now. Prior to these 3 weeks, the patient notes she felt like her mood was “normal”. When asked if she has ever had periods of abnormally elated mood or irritability, she notes that about 1 month ago she had a period where she felt “extremely happy”. States that she felt “the complete opposite” of how she felt currently. States this period lasted for approximately 5 days and she was “so so happy”. She also felt extremely productive during this time, cleaning her entire house in an evening, and that she was able to “take on more projects at work”. She also notes that she had increased energy, needing to only sleep about 2-3 hours a night during that time and feeling “amazing”. She has tried Zoloft in the past but discontinued the medication because it made her feel “hyper”. She currently is not taking any psychiatric medication. She has never been psychiatrically hospitalized before.
diagnosis_icd: Bipolar disorder with current depressed episode (F31.3)

diagnosis: F19.150 other psychoactive substance abuse with psychoactive substance induced psychotic disorder with delusions, F15.10 Other stimulant abuse, F12.1 Cannabis abuse
case: Patient F is a 37 year old male with past medical history of hypertension and past psychiatric history of substance use disorder (marijuana, methamphetamine) and psychosis who presents after being brought in by police to the ED for aggression. The patient was reportedly at a gas station causing a disturbance, speaking about how everyone in there was the devil and throwing items off the shelves. When officers arrived, the patient was aggressive and had to be tased. On arrival, the patient had to receive emergency IM medications of Haldol, Ativan, and Benadryl due to agitation. Psychiatry was consulted for psychosis. On psychiatric assessment, the patient is drowsy after having just received the emergency IM medications. However, he is irritable and hostile, telling the physician to “fuck off” and that “the devil is out to get you”. He states he is “like a God” and that he was unfairly arrested. On chart review, he has a history of being prescribed antipsychotics, but currently pt denies taking any psychiatric medications. Assessment was limited due to the patient’s lack of engagement and hostility. Lab work was significant for UDS positive for marijuana, methamphetamine, and PCP. He started on a low-dose of scheduled Risperidone. The next day, he was reassessed by psychiatry. He is less hostile, but still irritable and asks if he can sleep. On limited assessment, pt denied thinking the devil was after him and did not make any grandiose statements about him being God. He did not appear internally preoccupied but was very sleepy. He was later assessed in the afternoon after he was repotedly asking to leave. He denied suicidal ideations, homicidal ideations, or auditory/visual hallucinations. While he was still irritable, he was more cooperative and states he does not recall being at a gas station. He does endorse to using marijuana, methamphetamine, and PCP “for 2 days straight”. He is currently homeless and wants to go to the shelter. He denies paranoia or any belief that he is God, states “that’s ridiculous” when asked that question. Patient was then discharged after spending 24 hours in the ED.
diagnosis_dsm: Substance induced psychotic disorder, polysubstance use disorder
diagnosis_icd: F19.150 other psychoactive substance abuse with psychoactive substance induced psychotic disorder with delusions, F15.10 Other stimulant abuse, F12.1 Cannabis abuse

diagnosis: Post-traumatic stress disorder, chronic (F43.1); Alcohol use disorder, unspecified (F10.9)
case: Patient G is a 29 year old male with no past medical or psychiatric history who presents to his PCP for problems with sleep. The patient was discharged from the military 1 year ago after sustaining a combat-related injury while in Afghanistan. Since returning, he has been unable to sleep at night. He states he has difficulty falling asleep and staying asleep. He states he has recurring nightmares of what he witnessed while he was in Afghanistan, and these prevent him from sleeping. He also endorses avoidance of any loud noises such as fireworks as it triggers memories for him. He endorses hyper vigilance and always feels like he has to be aware of his surroundings. He states his mood has been “mad” and that he’s “always angry” for no reason and that this has caused difficulties between him and his wife. He does not go into detail about what he witnessed while deployed but does state that he regrets what he did and that he’s “a horrible person”. With regards to substance use, he endorses smoking 1 pack per day of cigarettes and drinking 6-beers a day, denies any illicit substances. He started drinking 6-beers a day ever since he returned from active duty and states “I never miss a day, it’s the only thing that helps me”. Patient was started on Zoloft and Trazodone for sleep and referred to a psychiatrist by his PCP.
diagnosis_icd: Post-traumatic stress disorder, chronic (F43.1); Alcohol use disorder, unspecified (F10.9)

diagnosis: Cataonia associated with another mental disorder (F06.1)
case: Patient H is a 36 year old female with a history of major depressive disorder (MDD) who presents to an inpatient psychiatric hospital for bizarre behavior. Her mother had called the police after she noticed the patient was acting bizarrely at home, not eating, staring blankly at the walls, and not attending to her hygiene. The patient was diagnosed with MDD when she was 20 years old and has been on Zoloft for years. However, she recently lost her insurance and has not been able to take her Zoloft for 6 months. The patient had previously worked full-time as an accountant and was married with 2 children. On assessment, the patient is mute with poor hygiene. Her face at times will scrunch during the interview. She sits motionless in a chair, not answering any questions. She stares blankly at the psychiatrist and is unable to engage. When asked if she can stick her tongue out, she does not follow the simple command. The psychiatrist conducts a musculoskeletal exam and when they move her arm, they are met initially with a large amount of resistance that slowly decreases with time. The psychiatrist moves the patient’s arm above her head, and the pt leaves it there after the psychiatrist lets go.
diagnosis_icd: Cataonia associated with another mental disorder (F06.1)

diagnosis: Schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type (F25.0)
case: Patient I is a 25 year old male with past medical history of hypertension and past psychiatric history of psychosis who presents to a psychiatric clinic for an initial evaluation due to hearing voices. The patient shares that he has been hearing voices for about 1 year. They initially started as incomprehensible whispers but have gradually become louder and more comprehensible. He states sometimes they will be bothersome and make negative remarks about him. He also states he has been isolating himself more and while he previously enjoyed spending time with his friends, he now has no desire to. He currently moved back in with his parents after being laid off from his job as an accountant due to missing multiple days of work unexcused. He denies any depression currently. When asked if he’s ever had episodes of an elated mood or irritability, he does state there was a period in the past year where he felt very happy. He says during this time he didn’t need to sleep as much, maybe 3-4 hours a night, had more energy, was productive, more sociable, and felt more motivated than before. He says people told him that he was “completely different” and people had a hard time understanding his speech, asking him to slow down. He says that lasted for a “couple weeks” and then it “went away”. He was still hearing voices at that time. His speech is tangential at times and he appears internally preoccupied. Hygiene is poor.
diagnosis_icd: Schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type (F25.0)

diagnosis: Bipolar disorder, current episode manic, severe, with psychotic features (F31.2)
case: Patient J is a 30 year old male with past medical history of hyperthyroidism and past psychiatric history of psychosis who presents to the inpatient psychiatric hospital after his family filed a community mental health warrant. Per his wife, the patient has not been sleeping for 2 weeks, not showering, yelling constantly at home, and took out their savings suddenly to open a restaurant. She states he has no restaurant experience and currently works as a plumber, never mentioning wanting to open a restaurant. She states he has been more violent at home, hitting her when she does not “do as he says” and endangering their 2 year old son. She gives an example of how he said that their son “should be able to bathe himself” and shut him in the bathroom by himself, not allowing the mother to enter. She also states he has been reaching out to multiple women on Instagram that he has never met before, asking them on a date and sending explicit photos to them. She has also noticed the patient talking to himself when no one is there. On assessment, the patient is irritable, loud, demanding to be released. Speech is rapid and pressured. He states, “nothing is wrong with me, I feel amazing, I am a God, I am the Messiah, you all are nothing”. He states that he has been “appointed” by God to “save humanity” and that he cannot do so while hospitalized. When asked about sleep, he states “I don’t need sleep, that is for the weak, I sleep maybe 1 hour and I feel amazing, I have good rest”. With regards to substance use, he denies cigarettes or alcohol use, does endorse buying delta 8 vapes from the smoke shop and smoking them. The wife states he started smoking these vapes about 6 months ago. He has seen a therapist before for depression but has never taken any psychiatric medications.
diagnosis_dsm: Bipolar I disorder, current episode manic, with psychotic features
diagnosis_icd: Bipolar disorder, current episode manic, severe, with psychotic features (F31.2)

diagnosis: Adjustment disorder with Mixed Anxiety and Depression (F43.23)
case: A 15-year-old Hispanic female with a history of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), stable on a low dose selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) for over a year, presented to the outpatient clinic with new-onset symptoms over the past 3–4 weeks including insomnia, panic attacks, and difficulty concentrating. The patient described a significant emotional event occurring two months ago: the death of her pet cat. She reported persistent crying spells, intrusive flashbacks of her cat’s death and burial, loss of appetite, and trouble falling asleep. She denied anhedonia, active or passive suicidal ideation, and maintained that she still enjoys going to school and spending time with friends and her younger sister. Despite these supports, she has noticed a decline in academic performance due to frequent, intrusive thoughts about her pet, particularly during class. She also reported an incident two weeks ago, when she became short of breath, diaphoretic and had experienced palpitations and had to excuse herself to “get some fresh air” in the middle of her music class. Washing face with cold water helped. Reported worrying about similar thing might happen again. During the evaluation, the patient presented with a constricted affect and became tearful while recalling memories of her cat but appeared more cheerful when discussing positive aspects of her life. She reported ongoing support from her mother, stepfather, and friends. Although she continues to engage in previously enjoyed activities like listening to music and socializing, she noted difficulty maintaining focus and occasionally “loses her train of thought” due to preoccupying memories of her cat—something she had never experienced before.
reasoning: This seems like adjustment disorder triggered by grief-related response. Criteria A: time line -developed within 3 months of the stressor; Criteria B: Impairment in functioning; Criteria C: Doesn’t seem like merely an exacerbation of her previous GAD and the depression, panic attacks, and intrusive thoughts are new.

diagnosis: Catatonia Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition (Catatonia due to known physiological condition F06.1)
case: A 20-year-old African American male with no prior psychiatric history presented to the emergency department with a one-week history of abnormal behavior, depressed mood, and headaches. He had been functioning well and working full-time until the onset of symptoms. One month prior, he had tested positive for COVID-19. Initial symptoms included anxiety, insomnia, depressed mood, and headache, which rapidly progressed to auditory hallucinations, paranoia, and functional impairment, raising concerns for an acute psychiatric or neurological process. On the third day of psychiatric hospitalization, the patient became selectively mute, immobile, and refused oral intake. He developed a low-grade fever and intermittent twitching of the right arm. Trials of haloperidol, benztropine, olanzapine, lorazepam, and hydroxyzine were ineffective. Due to the concern for seizures, he was transferred to an inpatient neurology unit. Workup included basic labs (within normal limits), unremarkable brain imaging, and an EEG showing moderate encephalopathy without epileptiform activity or clinical seizures. Autoimmune encephalitis was considered and investigated, but no definitive diagnosis was established. During neurology admission, there was no clinical improvement. Psychiatry was re-consulted, and the patient showed partial response to benzodiazepines. Gradual improvement was noted, with return of speech, mobility, and normalized vital signs. He was transferred to a long-term acute care facility, where he continued to improve. Within one month, he achieved full recovery and was discharged home.
reasoning: Catatonia Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition: here, encephalitis post COVID infection

diagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder single episode, severe, with catatonia (F32.2)
case: A 16-year-old Asian male with no prior psychiatric history presented to an outpatient clinic following concerns raised by his school nurse about dizziness, low blood pressure, and significant weight loss. The patient reported feeling overwhelmed with school and experiencing depressed mood over the past 6-8 months. School staff filed a CPS report due to concern for neglect, prompting an investigation that revealed poor nutritional status and recommended mental health and nutritional support. The patient had a low BMI and reported dizziness on standing, suggesting possible orthostatic hypotension secondary to malnutrition. On psychiatric evaluation, the patient appeared dysphoric with downcast eyes and exhibited significant thought blocking, though he was able to follow commands during the physical exam. He maintained a constricted affect and avoided eye contact. The patient disclosed feelings of being overwhelmed by academic pressure but provided limited verbal communication overall. He nodded yes when asked if he had recurrent death thoughts. Nodded yes when asked if he had a plan but didn’t disclose the plan. His family was unaware of the severity of his condition, though they acknowledged his recent withdrawal, tiredness, lack of appetite and weight loss. A history of school bullying was reported, though developmental history was otherwise unremarkable. Decision was made to voluntarily admit the patient. By the second day of inpatient psychiatric admission, the patient's condition deteriorated further. He stopped speaking entirely, refused to move, refused food, did not follow directions, and presented with staring and unusual mannerisms.
reasoning: MDD single episode, severe, with catatonia is important to discuss here because the condition would require treatment of catatonia first as it may be life threatening. Catatonia symptoms: stupor, mannerism, and negativism. It's important to treat catatonia and hence the diagnosis of catatonia should be made along with depression.

diagnosis: Post-partum psychosis (F53.1)
case: A 29-year-old female, 10-days postpartum, presented with her husband for new-onset command auditory hallucinations, decreased sleep, poor hygiene and paranoia. The patient has a diagnosis of bipolar 1 disorder, and stopped taking her medications at the beginning of pregnancy. The patient seemed very distant to her baby but denied any thoughts of harming the baby. This is the first time that patient experienced such symptoms, and she was admitted to the psychiatric unit for evaluation and management. Initial mental status exam on admission revealed flight of ideas, inappropriate laughter, paranoid delusions, distractibility, poor hygiene and hyper talkativeness. Laboratory tests were clinically unremarkable. Olanzapine was started and titrated appropriately. Melatonin and temazepam nightly were started to regulate her circadian rhythm. Due to lack of effect, olanzapine was changed to risperidone. After 1-week of admission, significant improvement in her symptoms were noticed. Her sleep condition stabilized initially, and she demonstrated a partial return to baseline functioning, with improved mood and cognition. The patient was discharged on day 10. However, after a week of her discharge, the patient experienced a relapse of some of her symptoms. She became increasingly agitated, paranoid, and starting responding to internal stimuli. The family later reported that they stopped giving the medication upon discharge as the patient seemed back to baseline and with a worry that the medications may be excreted in breast milk. Restarting psychotropics resulted in marked improvement, and the patient’s condition stabilized once again.
reasoning: This looks like post-partum psychosis mainly due to underlying bipolar disorder.

diagnosis: Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder (DMDD) (F34.81)
case: A 15-year-old male presented to outpatient follow-up after recent discharge from inpatient care following an incident in which he assaulted a male peer at school. During the visit, he appeared irritable, provided only one-word responses, and avoided eye contact. His parents reported that he has had longstanding behavioral difficulties, including chronic irritability, frequent angry outbursts, and academic struggles. The patient had to repeat fourth grade and also showing a recent decline in grades. Reached all milestones appropriately and denied history of trauma and abuse. At home, he has slammed the door during arguments. Socially, he has no friends and tends to isolate himself. He is good at basket-ball and tried for basketball team but was kicked out after he got into an argument with a peer. He lives with his biological mother and step father and loves to go for camping. He has 3 pet dogs and 2 cats (all adopted) and he is the primary care taker of all the pets. His school history is notable for getting into fights, including an episode of arguing with principal, when the principal didn’t listen to his justification after a fight with a peer. There is no indication of hallucinations or delusions, and no known substance use at this time.
reasoning: The patient’s presentation can easily be confused with Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD), however the chronic irritability, temper tantrums, academic impairment and overall timeline and frequency of symptoms favor more of DMDD symptoms. Interestingly, a child can-not be diagnosed with ODD and DMDD at the same time and hence its important to differentiate.

diagnosis: Excoriation (Skin-Picking) Disorder under Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders (F42.4)
case: A 77-year-old Caucasian female with a longstanding history of depression, anxiety, obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD), chronic musculoskeletal pain and cannabis use disorder, presented to the outpatient clinic with visible facial scarring due to persistent skin picking. The patient was calm, cooperative and logical in thought process. She reported that the recent behavior began a 6 weeks ago, a few weeks after the death of her two pet cats and also worsened in the context of ongoing other family-related psychosocial stressors such as death of her only sibling (brother) who was residing at a nursing home. The patient described a similar episode approximately 45 years ago following the “institutionalization of my brother”, when she witnessed the “shocking” treatment of her brother after his first psychotic episode. She reported that she picks her skin and doesn’t like the feel of scabs afterwards. She reported an intense desire to picks on her scabs which often bleed and she reported a sense of gratification immediately but feeling guilt and shame a few minutes later. She had to visit a dermatologist because of recent wound infection due to picking of her lower lip skin. She shared that her lower lip was extremely tender at that time. She tried wearing gloves to stop her behavior but she continues to pick at scabs and healing skin, particularly on her face. She is currently on the maximum dose of an SSRI and receives care for chronic back pain. The patient is a retired hypnotherapist and forensic psychologist, and tried self-hypnosis with no improvement. She also acknowledged that consuming news media worsens her anxiety and shared that she uses marijuana, which she believes helps her cope.
reasoning: Most common differential is OCD. Other differentials are substance use, worsening of mental health conditions and psychosis. The behavior emerged due to recent stress. The patient reported marked distress and have repeatedly tried to stop the behavior. Although she uses marijuana, substance use is chronic and there is no evidence that substance use is directly causing the picking. Dermatological causes were also evaluated and ruled out. Insight is preserved and the patient is not delusional or psychotic.

diagnosis: Schizophreniform disorder with good prognostic features (F20.81)
case: A 20-year-old male college student was brought in by campus security after exhibiting increasingly bizarre behavior, including social withdrawal, not eating or sleeping, and abrupt mood shifts. Family filed a police complaint after losing touch with him and his room-mate (knows the patient since elementary schools) is also present during the interview. Reported that the patient had been absent from classes for four weeks before suddenly returning, appearing disheveled and noticeably different from baseline. During the interview, the patient displayed slow, delayed speech that unexpectedly escalated in volume before he abruptly left mid-conversation without explanation. He had difficulty maintaining focus and gave vague or tangential responses. Making statements such as “god made me a rabbit and you are my master” and “I have killed multiple planets in my backyard”. Roommate reported that he had been isolating and making odd statements that "sometimes doesn’t make sense." But this is the worst he has seen him. For past two-three months or so, the patient stopped attending parties and classes. The patient has a history of chronic marijuana use since age 14, the roommate also reported that he tried “crack cocaine and mushrooms” last year during their Arizona trip but had a “bad trip” at that time and he has not witnessed any substance use since then. The patient is tested negative on a urine drug screen. Alcohol levels are normal. Creatinine kinase is significantly elevated but all other labs are normal. There is a significant family history of schizophrenia in father and mother had alcohol use disorder, who passed away from alcoholic cirrhosis.
reasoning: Timeline, first episode, clean drug screen, chronicity of symptoms, and level of functional decline.

diagnosis: Intermittent Explosive Disorder (IED) (F63.81)
case: A 16-year-old Hispanic female, immigrated to the United States two years ago from a conflict-affected region in South America, presented to the child psychiatry clinic for follow up evaluation and with recent complaints of frequent and severe verbal outbursts at school. The patient had a documented history of chronic sexual abuse and has also witnessed violence, both in her country of origin and during migration. She was accompanied by her biological mother. The patient presented for an initial evaluation six months ago and was lost to follow up since then. At that time, a diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) was made by the same outpatient mental health provider. The patient reported significant improvement in frequency and intensity of nightmares since started on medications six months ago. Re-established care because the school staff reported frequent episodes (occurring one-two times per week) in which the patient would become suddenly angry, shouting profanities and making personally hurtful comments toward teachers, administrators, and peers. These episodes were often precipitated by perceived criticism, sudden changes in expectations, or ambiguous social cues. Despite these outbursts, the patient was described as highly intelligent, academically capable, and frequently helpful to classmates. She was logical and articulate in conversations when calm but maintained a guarded and cautious interpersonal style. During clinical interview, the patient was initially reserved but opened up during the later parts of the interview. She endorsed persistent feelings of anger, mistrust, and fear, particularly in unfamiliar or male authority-driven environments. She denied hallucinations, current suicidal ideation, or substance use. Sleep disturbances, including frequent nightmares and early-morning awakenings, were reported. Cognitive assessment suggested average to above-average intellectual functioning, and no evidence of developmental delays or psychotic symptoms was noted or reported. Prior to migration, the patient had limited access to formal education, which appeared to contribute to a heightened sensitivity to perceived failure or criticism in the current school environment.

diagnosis: Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID) (F50.82)
case: An 18-year-old African American female was referred by her primary care provider (PCP) for evaluation of passive thoughts of death. The patient has been under her PCP’s care for persistent dizziness, failure to gain weight, persistent nausea and reported dysphagia. She presents with a complex psychosocial history. She lives with her single mother, following the death of her maternal grandmother, two years ago. Her maternal grandmother raised her since the age of 8 years old, shortly after her father died in a motor vehicle accident when she was eight years old, an event she witnessed, although she denies current post-traumatic stress symptoms. Despite significant personal hardship, she graduated early from high school and is currently working two jobs, though she expresses dissatisfaction with college and reports feeling disconnected from peers. Recently separated from her boyfriend of 1 year. Upon initial exam, the patient endorsed symptoms of low mood, irritability, and insomnia. She was tearful throughout the interview. Stated that she likes gardening and going out for walks. However, reported chronic poor appetite with nausea, fear of choking while eating, and has lost significant weight. Physical exam showed pale mucosa.  CBC shows iron-deficiency anemia, bradycardia, and irregular menses. Gastrointestinal and ENT evaluations, including imaging, esophagoscopy, and laryngoscopy, were unremarkable. Despite reported dysphagia, there are no structural findings. She attempted to use marijuana to increase her appetite, but found it ineffective. Socially, she has few supports and describes conflict with peers due to ongoing irritability.

diagnosis: Neurosyphilis (A52.3)
case: A 62 years old Caucasian male (previously married with two adult children, and was working full time but, currently homeless) with history of hypertension, diabetes, asthma, systolic heart failure, and anxiety presented to emergency department (ED) with complaints of lower body weakness, psychosis and irritability with law enforcement officer after the patient was found lying down in the middle of a moderately busy road. The officer mentioned he was awake with eyes open, talking to self and screaming intermittently, but couldn’t get up when asked to move. Upon evaluation by the provider, the patient was making statements such as “they are watching us with AI gadgets” and brought themes of paranoia in the conversations. Mental status exam showed a disheveled male with irritable mood, poor eye contact and disorganized thought process. Vital signs showed bradycardia and point of care glucose levels were 44 mg/dl. Urinary drug screen negative with normal alcohol levels. Otherwise, routine lab values of blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, urea, liver function tests, urinalysis, thyroid profile and vitamin b12 and folic acid were within normal limits. HIV screen negative, MRI scan of the head was unremarkable. Venereal Disease Research Laboratory test (VDRL) titres were 1:16.
reasoning: Psychiatric manifestations include dementia, delirium, depression, mania, personality changes, and psychosis.
